prompt: What does a meaningful life look like to you?
quote: The purpose of life is not to be happy. It is to be useful, to be honorable, to be compassionate.
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

prompt: What fear is holding you back from your true potential?
quote: Everything you want is on the other side of fear.
author: Jack Canfield

prompt: If you could give advice to your younger self, what would it be?
quote: We do not learn from experience... we learn from reflecting on experience.
author: John Dewey

prompt: What does inner peace mean to you, and how do you cultivate it?
quote: Peace comes from within. Do not seek it without.
author: Buddha

prompt: What limiting belief about yourself are you ready to let go of?
quote: The only person you are destined to become is the person you decide to be.
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

prompt: How do you want to be remembered by those who matter most?
quote: The purpose of life is to live it, to taste experience to the utmost, to reach out eagerly and without fear for newer and richer experience.
author: Eleanor Roosevelt

prompt: What would you do if you weren't afraid of failure?
quote: It is impossible to live without failing at something, unless you live so cautiously that you might as well not have lived at all.
author: J.K. Rowling

prompt: What truth about yourself have you been avoiding?
quote: The truth will set you free, but first it will piss you off.
author: Gloria Steinem

prompt: What would I do differently if I knew no one would ever find out?
quote: The privilege of a lifetime is to become who you truly are.
author: Carl Jung

prompt: If I had to explain my life's work to a wise stranger in one sentence, what would I say—and would I feel proud of it?
quote: The two most important days in your life are the day you are born and the day you find out why.
author: Mark Twain (attributed)

prompt: What am I currently optimizing for, and is that what I actually want to be optimizing for?
quote: The cost of a thing is the amount of what I will call life which is required to be exchanged for it, immediately or in the long run.
author: Henry David Thoreau

prompt: What belief have I held longest, and what would change if I questioned it today?
quote: It is the mark of an educated mind to be able to entertain a thought without accepting it.
author: Aristotle

prompt: When do I feel most like myself—and what does that reveal about the gap between my current life and my natural state?
quote: Everyone thinks of changing the world, but no one thinks of changing himself.
author: Leo Tolstoy

prompt: What pattern keeps repeating in my life, and what is it trying to teach me?
quote: Until you make the unconscious conscious, it will direct your life and you will call it fate.
author: Carl Jung

prompt: Who have I become in response to the people around me, and is that who I want to be?
quote: You are the average of the five people you spend the most time with.
author: Jim Rohn

prompt: What do I need to forgive myself for—not because it was okay, but because carrying it no longer serves me?
quote: We are products of our past, but we don't have to be prisoners of it.
author: Rick Warren

prompt: If I died today, what would I most regret not having done—and what's actually stopping me from starting it?
quote: The fear of death follows from the fear of life. A man who lives fully is prepared to die at any time.
author: Mark Twain

prompt: What am I doing out of momentum rather than intention?
quote: The unexamined life is not worth living.
author: Socrates

prompt: A year from now, what do I hope will be different about my inner life (not just my circumstances)?
quote: Yesterday I was clever, so I wanted to change the world. Today I am wise, so I am changing myself.
author: Rumi

prompt: What parts of my identity am I clinging to that no longer serve me?
quote: Life is a series of natural and spontaneous changes. Don't resist them; that only creates sorrow.
author: Lao Tzu

prompt: What would I create if I wasn't worried about being good at it?
quote: The master has failed more times than the beginner has even tried.
author: Stephen McCranie

prompt: What conversation am I avoiding, and what is that costing me?
quote: The single biggest problem in communication is the illusion that it has taken place.
author: George Bernard Shaw

prompt: Where in my life am I performing rather than being?
quote: To be yourself in a world that is constantly trying to make you something else is the greatest accomplishment.
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

prompt: What would my life look like if I stopped waiting for permission?
quote: Your time is limited, don't waste it living someone else's life.
author: Steve Jobs

prompt: What am I pretending not to know?
quote: Knowing yourself is the beginning of all wisdom.
author: Aristotle

prompt: If my life were a book, would I want to keep reading?
quote: Life isn't about finding yourself. Life is about creating yourself.
author: George Bernard Shaw

prompt: What does my calendar say about my priorities versus what I say my priorities are?
quote: You will never find time for anything. If you want time, you must make it.
author: Charles Buxton

prompt: What am I tolerating that I shouldn't be?
quote: We accept the love we think we deserve.
author: Stephen Chbosky

prompt: What skill or knowledge would change my life if I committed to learning it this year?
quote: An investment in knowledge pays the best interest.
author: Benjamin Franklin

prompt: What boundary do I need to set but haven't?
quote: Daring to set boundaries is about having the courage to love ourselves, even when we risk disappointing others.
author: Brené Brown

prompt: What story am I telling myself about why I can't have what I want?
quote: The only limits you have are the limits you believe.
author: Wayne Dyer

prompt: When was the last time I felt truly alive, and what was I doing?
quote: The purpose of life is to live it, not to spend forever wondering what it could have been.
author: Unknown

prompt: What would I do with my time if money were no object?
quote: The question isn't who is going to let me; it's who is going to stop me.
author: Ayn Rand

prompt: What am I grateful for that I often take for granted?
quote: Gratitude turns what we have into enough.
author: Melody Beattie

prompt: What does success actually mean to me, beyond what society tells me it should mean?
quote: Success is not the key to happiness. Happiness is the key to success.
author: Albert Schweitzer

prompt: What relationship in my life needs more attention, and what's preventing me from giving it?
quote: The most important thing in life is to learn how to give out love, and to let it come in.
author: Morrie Schwartz

prompt: What am I defending that's no longer worth defending?
quote: Sometimes letting things go is an act of far greater power than defending or hanging on.
author: Eckhart Tolle

prompt: If I could start over today, what would I do differently?
quote: It is never too late to be what you might have been.
author: George Eliot

prompt: What pain or discomfort am I numbing instead of addressing?
quote: The cave you fear to enter holds the treasure you seek.
author: Joseph Campbell

prompt: What does my ideal day look like, and how far am I from living it?
quote: The secret of your future is hidden in your daily routine.
author: Mike Murdock

prompt: What would I tell a friend who came to me with my exact problems?
quote: Talk to yourself like you would to someone you love.
author: Brené Brown

prompt: What am I sacrificing for comfort that I might need to sacrifice comfort for instead?
quote: A ship in harbor is safe, but that is not what ships are built for.
author: John A. Shedd

prompt: What version of myself am I becoming, and is that who I want to be?
quote: Be the change that you wish to see in the world.
author: Mahatma Gandhi

prompt: What am I waiting for the 'right time' to do that I could start today?
quote: The best time to plant a tree was 20 years ago. The second best time is now.
author: Chinese Proverb

prompt: What hard truth do I need to accept about my current situation?
quote: Acceptance doesn't mean resignation; it means understanding that something is what it is and that there's got to be a way through it.
author: Michael J. Fox

prompt: What would my 80-year-old self want me to know right now?
quote: In the end, it's not the years in your life that count. It's the life in your years.
author: Abraham Lincoln

prompt: What energizes me versus what drains me, and am I honoring that balance?
quote: Energy and persistence conquer all things.
author: Benjamin Franklin

prompt: What would I attempt if I knew I could not fail?
quote: Do not be afraid to give up the good to go for the great.
author: John D. Rockefeller
